title: Absence of CSRF Token Protection in Contact Form
description:
The contact form at the root endpoint lacks Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) token protection. The form has no hidden CSRF token field and no server-side token validation. The form element contains only basic HTML5 validation (required attributes and email type) but no security tokens. This allows an attacker to craft a malicious webpage that can automatically submit the contact form on behalf of a victim user without their knowledge or consent through a cross-origin request.

The vulnerability is confirmed through:
1. No CSRF token or nonce field present in form inputs
2. No validation of anti-CSRF tokens on form submission
3. Form submissions can be triggered from cross-origin requests
4. Complete reliance on client-side HTML5 validation only

The contact form is client-side only (no backend processing), which currently mitigates the practical impact. However, if a backend is added without CSRF protection, this would enable unauthorized form submissions leading to spam, phishing, or misinformation distribution.
impact: An attacker could craft a malicious webpage containing embedded form submissions that automatically send contact form data on behalf of a victim user. This enables spam distribution, phishing attacks, or automated abuse of the contact system. The victim's browser would unwillingly participate in submitting potentially harmful content. If a backend is implemented, unauthorized submissions could lead to data manipulation, spam proliferation, or system abuse.
evidence:
POC execution confirms:
- No CSRF token field found in form HTML
- Form element: <form id="contact-form" class="mx-auto" style="max-width: 600px;">
- Form inputs contain only: name (text), email (email) - no security tokens
- Form has no action attribute (defaults to same page submission)
- Form has no method attribute (defaults to GET)
- Vulnerability confirmed via automated scan showing no anti-CSRF mechanisms in place
- Cross-origin form submission is possible without token validation

POC Output:
[+] VULNERABILITY: No CSRF token field found in form
[+] VULNERABILITY CONFIRMED: No security tokens in form inputs
[+] Form is vulnerable to cross-origin form submission attacks
[+] Attacker could craft a malicious page to submit forms on behalf of users
remediation:
1. Implement server-side CSRF token generation and validation:
   - Generate a unique, cryptographically random token for each form instance
   - Store token in server-side session
   - Include token as hidden input in form: <input type="hidden" name="csrf_token" value="token_value">
   
2. Validate CSRF token on form submission:
   - Retrieve token from request
   - Compare against stored session token
   - Reject if missing or invalid
   
3. Implement additional CSRF defenses:
   - Validate Referer and Origin HTTP headers
   - Set SameSite=Strict on session cookies
   - Use double-submit cookie pattern as additional layer
   
4. Use security frameworks:
   - Consider using web frameworks with built-in CSRF protection (Django, Laravel, Express.js with csrf middleware)
   - These typically handle token generation, validation, and secure storage automatically
   
5. For frontend:
   - Use HTTPS only (prevent man-in-the-middle)
   - Implement proper CORS policies
   - Validate content-type headers
